detailedSummary: Authentication verifies user identity, while authorization determines what users can access. Common authentication methods include sessions (server-stored) and JWT (JSON Web Tokens, stateless). Password hashing uses bcrypt to store secure hashes, never plain text. JWT tokens contain user data and are signed for security. Token-based auth is stateless and scalable. Session-based auth stores session IDs server-side. Registration creates user accounts with validation. Login verifies credentials and issues tokens/sessions. Logout invalidates sessions/tokens. Password reset uses secure tokens. Authorization checks user permissions (roles, ownership). Protected routes require authentication. Middleware verifies tokens/sessions. OAuth enables third-party login (Google, GitHub). Understanding authentication and authorization is essential for securing applications and protecting user data.
whyItMatters: Authentication and authorization are critical for application security - they protect user data, enable personalized experiences, and control access to resources.

assignments.title: Implement Authentication System
assignments.description: Build a complete authentication system with registration, login, and protected routes.
tasks: Implement user registration with password hashing using bcrypt
Create login functionality that verifies credentials and issues JWT tokens
Build middleware to protect routes and verify authentication
Implement authorization to control access based on user roles
Create a complete authentication system with secure password handling and token management

quizzes.question: What is the main difference between authentication and authorization?
options: Authentication verifies identity, authorization determines access permissions
quizzes.explanation: Authentication verifies who a user is (login), while authorization determines what that user can access (permissions, roles).

quizzes.question: Passwords should be stored as plain text in the database for easy retrieval.
quizzes.explanation: False. Passwords must be hashed (using bcrypt or similar) before storage. Plain text passwords are a severe security vulnerability.

quizzes.question: What is JWT (JSON Web Token)?
options: A stateless authentication token that contains user data and is cryptographically signed
quizzes.explanation: JWT is a stateless authentication token format that contains user information and is cryptographically signed, enabling secure, scalable authentication.
